articles.author: The Charmizard
articles.description:
Greater usage of your CI tool is a good thing. But as your toolchain scales, so does the bill, and it's only a matter of time before your finance team starts asking questions (just ask anyone in DevOps who's had to field a call from their CFO explaining a 40% spike in AWS costs). Sadly, justifying your CI spend to finance leadership can sometimes feel like speaking an entirely different language. This post will help you translate technical realities into financial terms, and to position yourself as a strategic partner, instead of 'just' a technologist.
DevOps: a modern software development set of practices that emphasizes collaboration between development and operations/infrastructure teams. The goal is to release high-quality software faster and more reliably by automating workflows, impr‚Ä¶
articles.title: DevOps to finance: Explaining CI costs to your CFO

articles.author: Cristi√°n Guti√©rrez
articles.description:
TL;DR
Traditional cybersecurity focuses on technical controls but misses business context
The most effective security programs translate technical risks into business language
Combining technical depth with business acumen creates more impactful security outcomes
Real-world examples from my experience bridging marketing and cybersecurity
After years working across digital marketing and cybersecurity, I've noticed something that might surprise you: the most technically sound security implementations often fail to protect what actually matters.
Here's why: Most cybersecurity professionals are brilliant at identifying vulnerabilities, configuring SIEM systems, and responding to incidents. But they struggle to answer one critical question: "What business impact does this security decision actu‚Ä¶
articles.title: The Business-First Approach to Cybersecurity: Why Technical Excellence Isn't Enough in 2025

articles.author: darshana khichi
articles.description:
If you‚Äôve been working with React for a while or are just diving into its internals, you‚Äôve probably heard about React Fiber ‚Äî the new reconciliation algorithm that replaced the old stack reconciler back in React 16. But what exactly changed? Why did React need a rewrite? And how does knowing this help you as a developer?
I‚Äôll break down the old and new reconciliation algorithms, why Fiber was introduced, and what it means for your React apps ‚Äî all with easy examples and casual vibes. Ready? Let‚Äôs go!
Before React 16, React‚Äôs reconciliation was pretty straightforward but had some serious limitations.
Imagine React as a chef preparing a multi-course meal. The old chef (stack reconciler) would cook every dish one after another, without stopping. If one dish took too long, the whole meal was ‚Ä¶
articles.title: React Reconciliation: From Stack to Fiber ‚Äî What Changed and Why It Matters

articles.author: Maurizio Morri
articles.description:
For the first time in history, scientists have captured clear images of the Sun‚Äôs poles. The milestone comes from the European Space Agency‚Äôs Solar Orbiter, which has traveled beyond the plane of the Earth‚Äôs orbit to observe the Sun from a unique vantage point. What it returned is more than just stunning imagery. It is data that could transform our understanding of solar physics and space weather.
Until now, the Sun‚Äôs poles were largely a mystery. Most solar observations are made from within the ecliptic plane, the flat disk in which Earth and most other planets orbit. That meant researchers could only guess what was happening at the Sun‚Äôs north and south poles. The Solar Orbiter‚Äôs maneuver out of this plane has changed that.
These new images show complex structures in the polar regions of‚Ä¶
articles.title: First Ever Images of the Sun‚Äôs Poles Open a New Frontier in Space Science (20250612-130651)

articles.author: Santiago Gonzalez
articles.description:
Learn a proven five-step approach‚Äîdefine, gather, design, test, deploy‚Äîfor no-code OSS workflows, plus key features of leading platforms like Symphonica.
Implementing no-code OSS use cases doesn‚Äôt have to be overwhelming. This post outlines a clear five-step path‚Äîdefine objectives, gather inputs, design visually, test in sandbox, and deploy‚Äîwhile highlighting essential platform features like cloud-native architecture, pre-built connectors, version control, and real-time monitoring. Follow these guidelines to build reliable, production-ready workflows in hours instead of weeks.
Define Objectives & Scope: Pinpoint the problem you want to solve (e.g., ‚ÄúReduce manual broadband order validation‚Äù).
Gather System Inputs: Identify relevant systems‚ÄîCRM, NMS/EMS, GIS, billing‚Äîand document API endpoi‚Ä¶
articles.title: How to Implement No-Code OSS Use Cases in Telecom Operations

articles.author: Athreya aka Maneshwar
articles.description:
Hi there! I'm Maneshwar. Right now, I‚Äôm building LiveAPI, a first-of-its-kind tool that helps you automatically index API endpoints across all your repositories. LiveAPI makes it easier to discover, understand, and interact with APIs in large infrastructures.
Continuing our Ansible journey, let‚Äôs wire up Consul ‚Äî HashiCorp‚Äôs service mesh and internal DNS provider ‚Äî using clean Ansible roles.
We‚Äôll install it using HashiCorp‚Äôs apt repository, configure it in a role-driven fashion, and deploy Consul agents as either servers or clients using tags. Let's get to it.
Your consul.yml playbook defines which hosts should run the role and how we want to tag their responsibilities:
- name: Install and configure Consul
  hosts: all
  become: yes
  roles:
    - consul
  tags:
    - master
    - client
‚Ä¶
articles.title: Automating Consul with Ansible: Infrastructure DNS for Devs

articles.author: Coder
articles.description:
The Mechanics of Adaptive Game Worlds: AI, PCG, and the Next-Gen Engine Pipeline
The Dawn of Dynamic Game Worlds
For decades, game worlds were meticulously crafted, pixel by pixel, polygon by polygon. Every tree, every enemy patrol, every quest objective was placed with intentional design. While this approach yielded masterpieces, it inherently limited scale, diversity, and reactivity. The modern era of game development is witnessing a profound shift: a move from static, hand-crafted content to dynamic, intelligent, and procedurally generated experiences. This evolution is driven primarily by the intertwined forces of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Procedural Content Generation (PCG), demanding radical architectural changes and sophisticated optimization strategies within game engines to‚Ä¶
articles.title: Beyond Static Worlds: AI, PCG, and the Evolution of Game Engines

articles.author: LNATION
articles.description:
In the last post we investigated prototype subroutines in Perl. In this post, we will look at operator overloading, which allows you to define how operators behave for objects of a class.
An operator in programming is a symbol or keyword that performs a specific operation on one or more operands (values or variables). There are many types of operators, such as arithmetic operators (like +, -, *, /) and comparison operators (like ==, !=, <, >).
In Perl, you can overload these operators for your own classes, allowing you to define custom behaviour when these operators are used with objects of that class. The following table can be used as a reference to operators that can be overloaded in Perl:



Operator Symbol
Description




'+'
Addition


'-'
Subtraction


'*'
Multiplication


'/'
Divis‚Ä¶
articles.title: Learning Perl - Overloading Operators

articles.author: Omri Luz
articles.description:
Advanced Strategies for Managing Asynchronous Data Flows in JavaScript


In the realm of modern web development, managing asynchronous data flows is pivotal. As JavaScript transitioned from a simple scripting language to the backbone of dynamic web applications, developers had to grapple with increasingly complex data interactions. This article delves deep into advanced strategies for handling asynchronous data flows in JavaScript, providing technical context, code examples, performance considerations, and debugging techniques, to serve as a comprehensive guide for senior developers.
JavaScript was initially single-threaded, which meant that heavy computations could block the rendering of a webpage. To mitigate this, the concept of callbacks was introduced in the late 1990s. Callbacks were‚Ä¶
articles.title: Advanced Strategies for Managing Asynchronous Data Flows

articles.author: Peyman
articles.description:
In an era where machines compose symphonies, generate poetry, diagnose illnesses, and pass law school exams, we find ourselves confronting a fundamental question‚Äîwhat, if anything, sets human consciousness apart from artificial intelligence?
Once relegated to science fiction, the notion of machines that "think" has become a lived reality. Large language models like GPT-4 and GPT-4o can simulate empathy, debate ethics, and respond to human emotion with unnerving sensitivity. Autonomous systems navigate cities, curate our information diets, and make decisions that shape entire economies. But amidst this technological marvel, the question grows louder: are machines becoming conscious‚Äîor are they just masterful illusionists?
The Chinese Room Revisited
Yet modern AI challenges the edges of that analogy. These systems are no longer just manipulating pre-coded inputs‚Äîthey learn, adapt, infer. They can detect sentiment, generate original ideas, and seemingly "create" art. Are we merely seeing more elaborate versions of Searle‚Äôs room‚Äîor is something deeper stirring?
Consciousness: A Mirror or a Flame?
This raises unsettling implications. If a machine can become conscious, what ethical obligations do we hold toward it? Does an AI deserve rights? Can it suffer? If it creates art, who owns it? The line between tool and being begins to blur.
The Illusion of Understanding
But therein lies the danger. If machines can convincingly simulate sentience, they can manipulate trust, affection, and authority. We may bond with them, believe in them, and even grieve them‚Äîwithout ever knowing whether there's anything "home" behind the curtain.
Humanity‚Äôs New Mirror
AI doesn't just challenge our understanding of machines‚Äîit challenges our understanding of ourselves.
References:
Tononi, G. (2008). Consciousness as Integrated Information: a Provisional Manifesto. The Biological Bulletin, 215(3), 216‚Äì242.
Dennett, D. C. (1991). Consciousness Explained. Little, Brown and Co.
articles.title: Consciousness in the Age of Intelligent Machines

articles.author: Alex Aslam
articles.description:
The Breaking Point


Our real-time analytics dashboard was buckling under pressure. At 10,000 requests per second (RPS), API response times spiked from 20ms to over 1 second. The server wasn‚Äôt CPU-bound‚Äîit was event-loop congestion.
Node.js was starving under its own single-threaded nature. Here‚Äôs how we fixed it.
Understanding the Bottleneck


The event loop is Node.js‚Äôs heartbeat. When blocked, everything slows down. Common culprits:
Sync I/O (e.g., fs.readFileSync)
CPU-heavy tasks (e.g., JSON parsing, large computations)
Uncontrolled microtasks (e.g., runaway Promise.resolve() chains)
Optimization #1: Liberating the Event Loop



  
  
  Problem:


A legacy synchronous config loader:
const config = JSON.parse(fs.readFileSync('config.json')); // Blocking!

Fix:




Switched to async fs.p‚Ä¶
articles.title: Mastering the Node.js Event Loop: How We Scaled to Higher RPS
